Unit 2: Building Your Professional Profile - Session 1

The majority of a learning resource will be establishing context, delivering instructions and providing general information. This provides the framework within which the learning activities are built and delivered.
Use this field to enter text. This iDevice has no emphasis applied although limited formatting can be applied to text through the text editing buttons associated with the field.

Introduction to Unit 2, Session 1: Building Your Professional Profile

Welcome

Welcome to Session of Unit 2: Building Your Professional Profile! In this session, weâ€™ll explore how to define your goals, build key workplace skills, and reflect on what success means for you in todayâ€™s professional world.

You will:

  • Read a motivational article about goal setting and professional success
  • Practise strategies to improve your reading skills
  • Learn vocabulary related to personal development, motivation, and workplace skills
  • Review impersonal structures to express general advice and opinions

ðŸ’¡ What Will You Discover Today?

  • Why setting specific goals is essential for your career
  • Which personal and professional skills help you succeed at work
  • How to express advice using formal and neutral English structures (e.g., It is important toâ€¦ / You shouldâ€¦)

This session combines reading and grammar practice to help you reflect on your future career. Youâ€™ll start by reading a practical and inspiring text, followed by work on vocabulary and grammar structures that will support your professional communication in English.

Letâ€™s begin!

Get ready to shape your professional journey with practical skills and confident English!

âœ¨ Start now and build your path to success!

ðŸ“– Reading Practice: Setting Goals and Workplace Success

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

This reading practice helps you understand how to set goals and succeed in the workplace. The text combines advice on planning your future with tips for mastering key work skills, perfect for vocational fields like social integration or logistics. Use these strategies to read effectively:

  • Skim first: Read the title and headings to get the main idea.
  • Scan for details: Look for specific information, like examples or numbers, to answer questions.
  • Guess meaning: Use context to understand new words (e.g., â€œprioritizeâ€ means â€œput firstâ€).
  • Take notes: Jot down key points to help you remember.

Answer the pre-reading questions to think about the topic, then read the text and complete the comprehension activities. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

Scoring: Each correct answer is worth 1 point (16 points total). Score 13 or more (â‰ˆ80%) to confirm strong comprehension. If you score less than 13, review the text and try again.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Read actively by asking yourself what each paragraph is about!

ðŸ¤” Pre-Reading Questions

Instructions: Think about these questions to prepare for the text. You can discuss them with a partner or write your answers, but they are not scored.

  • 1. What is one goal you have for your future (e.g., study, work, travel)?
  • 2. What skill do you think is most important for success at work? Why?
  • 3. How do you stay motivated when working on a difficult task?

ðŸ’¡ Tip: These questions help you connect the text to your own life!

ðŸ“œ Reading Text

Navigating Your Future: Setting Goals and Mastering Success

By Fernando Braunza Asensio, CIDEAD Magazine, March 2025

In todayâ€™s fast-paced world, planning your future and mastering key skills at work are essential steps toward achieving your dreams and building a successful career. Whether youâ€™re finishing high school, starting a new job, or aiming to grow in your current role, setting clear goals acts like a personal GPS system to guide you toward your aspirations, while developing workplace skills can help you excel professionally. This article explores how to set achievable goals and apply practical strategies to thrive in both personal and professional settings.

Setting Goals for Your Future

Setting goals is the first step to turning your dreams into reality. Clear and specific goals give you a target to aim for, making it easier to track your progress. For example, instead of saying, â€œI want to be successful,â€ try, â€œI aim to start my own sustainable business within five years.â€ Specific goals keep you focused and motivated.

To succeed, set achievable targets. Big dreams are important, but breaking them into smaller steps helps you stay motivated. For instance, if your goal is to study abroad, start by researching programs or saving money each month. These small actions build momentum toward your larger vision.

Prioritize your goals based on what matters most to you. Some goals, like finding a part-time job to fund your education, may need immediate attention, while others, like learning a new language, can be long-term. Create a timeline using tools like calendars or apps to set deadlines and stay on track. Deadlines create urgency and help you avoid procrastination.

Stay adaptable, too. Life brings surprises, and itâ€™s okay to adjust your goals as your interests evolve. Flexibility ensures your goals remain relevant. Finally, celebrate your achievements, no matter how small. Rewarding yourselfâ€”like enjoying a movie night or time with friendsâ€”keeps you motivated for the journey ahead.

Mastering Keys for Success at Work

Once youâ€™ve set your goals, mastering key workplace skills can help you achieve them. Effective communication is essential. Clear communication involves expressing your ideas well, listening actively, and understanding your colleaguesâ€™ perspectives. Good communication builds trust and sets you apart in any workplace.

A positive attitude is another key to success. Staying optimistic boosts your motivation and inspires those around you. A positive mindset helps you handle challenges and creates a productive work environment. Even on tough days, a smile and proactive approach can make a big difference.

Time management is also crucial. Prioritizing tasks, setting realistic goals, and using your time efficiently increase your productivity. For example, making a daily to-do list can help you focus on whatâ€™s most important. Working smarter, not harder, is the secret to getting more done.

Continuous learning keeps you competitive. Stay updated on industry trends, take courses, or learn new skills to stay ahead. For instance, learning digital tools can open new career opportunities. Seeking feedback from colleagues or mentors also helps you improve.

Finally, build strong relationships. Networking with colleagues, mentors, and professionals provides support and opens doors. Genuine connections, built on trust, are more valuable than just collecting contacts. Attend work events or join professional groups to grow your network.

Conclusion

Setting clear goals and mastering workplace skills are powerful tools to shape a bright future. By defining your vision, taking actionable steps, and staying committed, you lay a strong foundation for personal success. At the same time, developing skills like communication, positivity, time management, continuous learning, and networking helps you thrive in the workplace. Embrace this journey with focus and flexibility, and watch as your goals and skills propel you toward a fulfilling career and life.

âœ… Exercise 1: Multiple Choice (6 items)

Instructions: Choose the correct answer for each question based on the text. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. What is the main purpose of setting specific goals?

  • 2. Why should you break goals into smaller steps?

  • 3. What does the text suggest about deadlines?

  • 4. What is one benefit of effective communication at work?

  • 5. How can a positive attitude help at work?

  • 6. Why is continuous learning important?

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Look for key words in the text to find the right answer!

ðŸ” Exercise 2: True/False (6 items)

Instructions: Decide if each statement is true or false based on the text. Select the correct option. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 7. You should never change your goals.
    True False
  • 8. Celebrating small achievements helps motivation.
    True False
  • 9. Time management means working longer hours.
    True False
  • 10. Networking is only about collecting contacts.
    True False
  • 11. A daily to-do list can improve time management.
    True False
  • 12. Positive attitude has no effect on colleagues.
    True False

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Check the text for details to confirm if the statement is correct!

ðŸ“ Exercise 3: Open-Ended Questions (4 items)

Instructions: Answer each question based on the text or your own ideas. Type your answers in the text box. Click "Check Answers" for feedback. (Note: Answers may vary, but feedback will guide you.)

  • 13. Name one example of a specific goal mentioned in the text.

  • 14. What is one way to improve time management, according to the text?

  • 15. Name one workplace skill you want to improve and why.

  • 16. Why do you think setting goals is important for your future?

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use the text for ideas, but feel free to add your own thoughts!

ðŸ§© Use of English â€“ Unit 2: Session 1

Welcome

Welcome to the Use of English section of Unit 2, Session 1! In this session, weâ€™re going to focus on some very useful grammar structures that will help you speak and write in a more professional and formal way.

You will work with three types of impersonal structures that are common in business English:

  • It is + adjective + to + verb â€“ to give advice or express general opinions
  • There is / There are â€“ to introduce facts, ideas or possibilities
  • One / We + verb â€“ to generalise or speak in a formal/inclusive way

Steps

This section is divided into three steps:

  • Diagnostic Test â€“ Check what you already know
  • Grammar Lesson â€“ Learn and reflect with real examples
  • Grammar Practice â€“ Consolidate your learning with guided activities

ðŸŽ¯ Why This Matters

Using these structures correctly will help you:

  • Sound more confident and professional
  • Adapt to formal and workplace contexts
  • Communicate ideas clearly and objectively

Ready? Letâ€™s begin with the diagnostic test!

Dive into this section to boost your professional English skills!

âœ¨ Start now and take your communication to the next level!

ðŸ§ª Introduction to Diagnostic Test â€“ Unit 2, Session 1

ðŸ§ª Get Ready to Check Your Grammar!

Before we jump into grammar explanations, letâ€™s stop for a moment and check what you already know. This short diagnostic test will help you review three key grammar points used in professional communication:

  • It is + adjective + to + verb â€“ to give advice and recommendations
  • There is / There are â€“ to present facts and possibilities
  • One / We + verb â€“ to speak in a general, formal or inclusive way

This is not a test for marks. Itâ€™s a tool to help you learn more about your own learning.

ðŸŽ¯ Whatâ€™s the Goal?

To help you decide if you need to review the grammar in this session â€” or if youâ€™re ready to move on.

ðŸ“˜ How?

Do the test and check your answers with the Answer Key at the end.

  • âœ… If you score 80% or more: you can skip the grammar explanation and go directly to the practice.
  • ðŸ“Œ If you score less than 80%: take a few minutes to review â€” itâ€™ll be worth it!

This activity helps you develop your Competence to Learn to Learn and your Competence for Lifelong Learning. Letâ€™s get started!

Take this test to shape your learning path and build confidence in your grammar skills!

âœ¨ Dive in and discover your strengths!

ðŸ“‹ Impersonal Structures Diagnostic Practice (B1)

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

This diagnostic test checks how well you use impersonal structures like "It is," "There is/are," and "One should" in professional English. Answer all 20 questions in four parts to see if you can skip the grammar section. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

Scoring: Each correct answer is worth 1 point (20 points total). Score 16 or more (80%+) to skip the grammar section. If you score less than 16, review the impersonal structures lesson.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Think about whether the sentence needs "It is," "There is/are," or "One should"!

ðŸŸ  Exercise 1: Multiple Choice (6 items)

Instructions: Choose the correct sentence. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1.

  • 2.

  • 3.

  • 4.

  • 5.

  • 6.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Look for the correct verb form after "It," "There," or "One"!

ðŸŸ¡ Exercise 2: Complete the Sentence (7 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence with 1â€“2 missing words. Type the exact words (e.g., "is important"). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 7. It is __________ to focus on your goals.

  • 8. There __________ a great opportunity to improve.

  • 9. __________ should always be respectful to colleagues.

  • 10. It is __________ to manage your time effectively.

  • 11. There __________ no easy solution to this problem.

  • 12. We often __________ to ask for help when we need it.

  • 13. One __________ adapt to different work cultures.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use "It is," "There is/are," or a modal like "should" to fill the blanks!

ðŸ”´ Exercise 3: Spot the Mistake and Correct It (4 items)

Instructions: The sentences below have a mistake. Type the corrected phrase (e.g., "to learn"). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 14. It is helpful learn new skills. â†’ Correct: ____________________

  • 15. There is many people in the room. â†’ Correct: ____________________

  • 16. One should studies hard to succeed. â†’ Correct: ____________________

  • 17. We needs to improve our communication. â†’ Correct: ____________________

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Check the verb form or agreement with "It," "There," or "One"!

ðŸŸ¢ Exercise 4: Choose the Correct Structure (3 items)

Instructions: Choose the correct structure to complete each sentence. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 18. ________ a lot of emails to answer today.

  • 19. ________ to ask questions if something is not clear.

  • 20. ________ should always check the meeting time twice.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Choose the structure that fits the sentence context!

ðŸ§  Grammar Focus â€“ Unit 2, Session 1: Impersonal Structures in Professional English

Introduction

Unit 2 helps you communicate professionally in vocational fields like social integration or logistics. This Grammar Focus explores impersonal structures, which let you give advice or describe situations objectively, perfect for formal emails, reports, or presentations in the workplace.

In professional communication, we often need to give advice, express general ideas, or describe common situations. To do this, we use impersonal structures. These structures help us speak or write in a more formal and objective way â€” especially when we are not talking about a specific person.

In this section, you will learn how to recognise and use different types of impersonal structures that are common in professional and academic English. You will also see how these phrases are used in real texts and practise using them in context.

In this section, we will explore:

  • It is + adjective + to + verb â†’ It is important to plan ahead
  • There is / There are â†’ There are many ways to improve your skills
  • One / We + verb â†’ One should always be respectful / We often forget how useful teamwork is

Letâ€™s take a closer look at each of these structures and learn how to use them to communicate clearly and professionally.
ðŸŽ§ Complementary Audio â€“ Guided Explanation
This audio supports you as you go through the lesson. Listen to it for a step-by-step explanation with spoken examples. Itâ€™s especially helpful if you prefer learning by listening or want to review while doing other tasks.

ðŸ”¹ It is + adjective + to + verb

This structure acts like a frame to judge or describe an actionâ€™s quality, such as being important or difficult, without pointing to anyone specific. Itâ€™s a way to share advice or opinions formally, keeping the focus on the action itself.

This structure is very common in professional and academic English. We use it when we want to give general advice, express opinions, or talk about something that is important, necessary, easy, difficult, etc., without mentioning a specific person.

Structure:

It is + adjective + to + base form of the verb

Examples:

  • It is important to be on time.
  • It is easy to make mistakes when you are in a hurry.
  • It is helpful to plan your goals in advance.

This construction allows you to sound more formal and professional. It also helps you write or speak more impersonally, which is useful in business communication and academic writing.

Be careful!

Do not confuse this structure with â€œItâ€™s + adjective + that...â€, which usually requires a full clause and different grammar.

Letâ€™s now look at some common adjectives that are used in this structure:

  • important â€“ It is important to listen carefully.
  • necessary â€“ It is necessary to be polite during a meeting.
  • helpful â€“ It is helpful to write things down.
  • easy / difficult â€“ It is easy to forget names / It is difficult to work under pressure.

ðŸ”¹ There is / There are

Imagine this structure as setting a stage to introduce ideas, situations, or possibilities. It highlights what exists or is available in a neutral, general way, keeping the focus on the topic rather than the speaker.

The expressions â€œThere isâ€ and â€œThere areâ€ are used to introduce information or ideas, especially when we want to speak generally and formally. These structures help us describe situations, give examples, or present possibilities in a neutral way.

Structure:

There is + singular / uncountable noun

There are + plural noun

Examples:

  • There are many ways to improve your skills.
  • There is a need for better time management in many jobs.
  • There are several strategies you can use to stay motivated.
  • There is always room for improvement.

This structure is very useful when writing reports, presentations or formal emails. It helps to keep the focus on the idea, not on the speaker.

We also use â€œThere is / areâ€ with modal verbs or quantifiers to give advice or highlight possibilities:

  • There can be misunderstandings if communication is not clear.
  • There may be different ways to approach the same problem.

Tip: This structure is often used at the beginning of a paragraph to introduce a topic or idea.

ðŸ”¹ One / We + verb

This structure lets you adopt a shared or general perspective, like speaking for a group or society. â€œOneâ€ creates a formal, distant tone, while â€œWeâ€ feels inclusive, inviting others into the idea.

We can also express general ideas using â€œoneâ€ (more formal) or â€œweâ€ (more inclusive). These subjects help us talk about common situations, habits or advice without referring to a specific person.

Structure:

One + verb (formal)

We + verb (neutral / inclusive)

Examples:

  • One should always be respectful in the workplace. (formal)
  • One can learn a lot from experience. (formal)
  • We often forget how useful teamwork is. (inclusive)
  • We need to stay motivated to reach our goals. (inclusive)

â€œOneâ€ is typically used in written or formal English, especially in articles or official documents. â€œWeâ€ is more common in presentations, general communication, or when the speaker includes themself in the group.

This structure is very useful in professional situations when you want to make general statements or share common advice in a respectful and polite way.

Tip: In job interviews or presentations, â€œweâ€ is often used to show that you are a team player or that you share common values with others.

In the next activity, you will practise choosing the right structure depending on the level of formality and the context.

Try writing a short paragraph for a workplace report using at least two of these structures to give general advice or describe a situation.

âœ¨ Master these structures to communicate with confidence and professionalism!

ðŸ“‹ Impersonal Structures Practice

ðŸŽ¯ Introduction

Master impersonal structures from Unit 2, Session 1 to communicate professionally in fields like social integration or logistics! These activities help you use "It is + adjective + to + verb" (frame for advice), "There is/are" (stage for ideas), and "One/We + verb" (shared perspective) in formal emails or reports. Complete the 24 items across four exercises. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

Scoring: Each correct answer is worth 1 point (24 points total). Aim for 19 or more (â‰ˆ80%) to confirm readiness. If you score less than 19, review the grammar lesson.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Think about the context and formality to choose the right structure!

â“ Exercise 1: Multiple Choice â€“ Choose the Correct Structure (6 items)

Instructions: Choose the correct impersonal structure to complete each sentence. Select from the dropdown. Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 1. ___ important to be on time for meetings.

  • 2. ___ many opportunities to learn new skills.

  • 3. ___ should always listen to colleagues.

  • 4. ___ necessary to plan your tasks carefully.

  • 5. ___ a need for better communication in teams.

  • 6. ___ often need to work together to succeed.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Check if the sentence needs a frame, stage, or shared perspective!

ðŸ“ Exercise 2: Gap-Fill â€“ Complete the Sentence (6 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence with the correct impersonal structure (1â€“2 words). Type the exact words (e.g., "It is"). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 7. ___ helpful to ask for feedback regularly.

  • 8. ___ several strategies to stay organized.

  • 9. ___ should be polite in emails.

  • 10. ___ difficult to manage stress sometimes.

  • 11. ___ always a way to solve problems.

  • 12. ___ often forget to take breaks.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Use "It is," "There is/are," or "One/We" based on the sentence!

ðŸ” Exercise 3: Sentence Correction â€“ Fix the Mistake (6 items)

Instructions: The sentences below have a mistake in the impersonal structure. Type the corrected phrase (e.g., "to be"). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 13. It is necessary be on time. â†’ Correct: ___

  • 14. There is many solutions to this issue. â†’ Correct: ___

  • 15. One should to learn new skills. â†’ Correct: ___

  • 16. We needs to be patient. â†’ Correct: ___

  • 17. It is easy make mistakes. â†’ Correct: ___

  • 18. There are a problem with the schedule. â†’ Correct: ___

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Check the verb form or agreement in the structure!

ðŸ“Š Exercise 4: Sentence Completion â€“ Workplace Context (6 items)

Instructions: Complete each sentence with the correct impersonal structure based on the workplace context. Type the exact words (e.g., "There are"). Click "Check Answers" for feedback.

  • 19. In a team, ___ should always communicate clearly.

  • 20. ___ a need for better logistics planning.

  • 21. ___ important to check emails daily.

  • 22. ___ often learn from our mistakes.

  • 23. ___ several ways to improve teamwork.

  • 24. ___ helpful to set clear goals.

ðŸ’¡ Tip: Think about formality and context (e.g., formal report or team talk)!

Click "Check Answers" in each section to see your score.
